title: 108_s180
content: The Act includes a table of contents with two main titles: National Aviation Heritage Area and Wright Company Factory Study. The National Aviation Heritage Area title covers definitions, management plan, administration, and authorization of appropriations. The Wright Company Factory Study title includes definitions, a study, and a report. The National Aviation Heritage Area includes definitions for Heritage Area, Management entity, Management plan, Partner, and Secretary. The National Aviation Heritage Area defines the term "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 103. NATIONAL AVIATION HERITAGE AREA. The National Aviation Heritage Area is established in Ohio and Indiana, including specific core areas and landmarks like the Neil Armstrong Air & Space Museum and the Wilbur Wright Birthplace and Museum. The Secretary will prepare a map outlining the boundaries of the Heritage Area. The Secretary will prepare a map of the National Aviation Heritage Area for inclusion in the management plan, which will be available for public inspection in National Park Service offices. The management plan for the National Aviation Heritage Area will include a map prepared by the Secretary and available for public inspection in National Park Service offices. The management entity must submit a management plan for the Heritage Area to the Secretary within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The plan should integrate protection, enhancement, and interpretation of natural, cultural, historic, scenic, and recreational resources, consider Federal, State, and local plans, involve residents and organizations, and include an assessment of cultural landscapes and provisions for resource protection and enjoyment. The management plan for the Heritage Area must include an interpretation plan, a program for implementation by the management entity, collaboration among partners for heritage tourism promotion and educational programs, assistance for restoration and construction plans, and maximizing practicable efforts. The management plan for the Heritage Area should include specific commitments from partners for the first 5 years of operation, an inventory of resources in the core area including the Dayton Aviation Heritage Historical Park, sites listed in the Dayton Aviation Heritage Preservation Act of 1992, and other related properties for preservation. The management plan for the Heritage Area should include commitments from partners for the first 5 years, an inventory of resources in the core area, sources of funding, and details about the management entity. Failure to submit the plan on time will result in a halt of additional funding until the plan is submitted. Approval or disapproval of management plans will be determined by the Secretary. The Secretary approves or disapproves management plans within 90 days of receipt. If disapproved, recommendations for revisions are provided, and a revised plan must be approved within 90 days. Amendments to the plan can be made as needed. The Secretary reviews and approves amendments to the management plan that may bring substantial changes before funds can be used for implementation. SEC. 105. ADMINISTRATION. The management entity administers the Heritage Area according to the title, using Federal funds for grants, agreements, staff, goods, services, and obtaining funds from any source. They prioritize implementing actions set forth in the management plan. The management entity gives priority to implementing actions in the management plan, assists in preserving resources, encourages land use policies consistent with the plan, considers diverse interests, promotes heritage tourism, and assists partners in educational and cultural development. The management entity prioritizes implementing actions in the management plan, preserves resources, encourages land use policies consistent with the plan, promotes heritage tourism, and assists partners in developing educational and cultural programs for the public. It also aims to encourage economic viability in the Heritage Area and support government and nonprofit organizations in various initiatives such as interpretive exhibits, recreational resources, public awareness, and installing clear signs throughout the area. The management entity implements actions in the management plan, preserves resources, promotes heritage tourism, and supports partners in developing educational programs. It conducts public meetings, submits amendments to the plan for approval, and reports activities and expenses to the Secretary for any fiscal year with Federal funds. The management entity must provide records for audit, prohibit the use of Federal funds for acquiring real property, and allows the use of non-Federal funds for property acquisition. SEC. 106. TECHNICAL AND FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE; OTHER FEDERAL AGENCIES. The Secretary may provide technical and financial assistance to the Heritage Area management entity for the development and implementation of the management plan. This assistance can be reimbursable or nonreimbursable, and cooperative agreements can be made with other organizations for assistance. Priority is given to actions that help conserve historical, cultural, and natural resources of the Heritage Area. The Secretary may provide operational assistance to public or private organizations in the Heritage Area to support the implementation of the management plan. Federal agencies conducting activities affecting the Heritage Area must consult and cooperate with the Secretary and the management entity. The Secretary may provide operational assistance to organizations in the Heritage Area to implement the management plan. Coordination between the Secretary, Secretary of Defense, and Administrator of NASA is required for decisions regarding properties under their jurisdiction. Authorization of appropriations for Title II is set at $10,000,000 with a limit of $1,000,000 per fiscal year. The Federal share of total costs for assisted activities should not exceed 50 percent. The authority to provide assistance under this title ends 15 years after the enactment of the Act. Definitions for "Factory," "Park," and "Secretary" are provided in Title II. The Secretary is required to conduct a special resource study to update a previous study and explore options for incorporating the Factory into the Park. The study will analyze management and development alternatives, consulting with various organizations and interested parties. The Secretary is mandated to submit a report to Congress within 3 years of funds being allocated, detailing the outcomes of the study conducted under this title. This is in relation to the establishment of the National Aviation Heritage Area.
